medium: Enamel and acrylic on canvas with objects attached
creditline: Gift of Stanley J. Seeger Jr., Class of 1952, in memory of his mother Helen B. Seeger, on the date of her birthday, through the Helen B. Seeger Fund
inscribed:
Each panel inscribed in charcoal, verso, (left to right):
a.) "Spring sprayed with the help of some nitrogen"
b.) "Spring spraying nitrogen"
c.) "Spring spraying nitrogen"
d.) ""The Art of Painting" #2 Second Series"
e.) ""The Art of Painting" (Second Series)"
signed:
Each panel signed and dated in charcoal, verso, (left to right):
a.) Jim Dine 1973, Putney
b.) Jim Dine 1973
c.) Jim Dine 1973
d.) Jim Dine 1973
e.) Jim Dine, 1973

makers.displaydate: born 1935, Cincinnati, OH; active New York, NY
makers.displaymaker: Jim Dine, born 1935, Cincinnati, OH; active New York, NY

texts.textentryhtml: Helen B. Seeger Fund, gift; to Princeton University Art Museum, 1974.

In an effort to move the art of painting beyond the strict limits of the flat picture plane, Jim Dine often staged irreverent, disquieting, and informally scripted Happenings early in his career. In these performances, which frequently involved the audience, Dine utilized hand-painted sets and props in a way that had a profound effect on his later studio practice. Here, tools suspended from multiple canvases riddle the distinctions between painting and sculpture and two- and three-dimensionality; they also seem to invite the viewer to take up the art of painting. The combination of real brushes and gardening tools suggests a humorous twist on landscape painting, which here is equated with the pedestrian activities of weeding and planting.

In an effort to move the art of painting beyond the strict limits of the flat picture plane, Jim Dine often staged irreverent, disquieting, and informally scripted Happenings early in his career. In these performances, which frequently involved the ­audience, Dine utilized hand-painted sets and props in a way that had a profound effect on his later studio practice. Suspending implements from multiple canvases as he does here puts the work’s identity in doubt. Are we looking at a painting or a sculpture or both? The combination of real brushes and gardening tools also suggests a humorous twist on landscape painting, which is here equated with the pedestrian activity of weeding and planting.
